IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 15733 S0926-860X(16)30018-7 10.1016/j.apcata.2016.01.018 Scheme 1 The possible reaction routes of the 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation. Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of CNTs with different treated methods: CNTs-1 (a), CNTs-2 (b), CNTs-3 (c), CNTs-4 (d). Fig. 2 TPD results of CNTs with different treated methods: CNTs-1 (a), CNTs-2 (b), CNTs-3 (c), CNTs-4 (d). Fig. 3 Pore size distributions of CNTs with different treated methods: CNTs-1 (a), CNTs-2 (b), CNTs-3 (c), CNTs-4 (d). Fig. 4 XRD patterns of Ni/CNTs-1 (a), Ni/CNTs-2 (b), Ni/CNTs-3 (c), Ni/CNTs-4 (d). Fig. 5 The SEM images of the supported nickel catalysts: Ni/CNTs-1 (a), Ni/CNTs-2 (b), Ni/CNTs-3 (c), Ni/CNTs-4 (d). Fig. 6 The TEM images of the supported nickel catalysts: Ni/CNTs-1 (a) and Ni/CNTs-4 (b). Fig. 7 The FT-IR spectra of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine intermediate product. Table 1 Results of Boehm titration of the CNTs samples with different treatment methods. Table 9 The reusability of the Ni/CNTs-4 for the 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation. a Run t(min) Conversion (%) Selectivity (%) TOF (s−1) 1,5-diaminonaphthalene others 1 120 100 92.04 7.96 1.043 2 210 100 91.19 8.81 0.591 3 220 100 91.17 8.83 0.564 4 240 100 91.11 8.89 0.516 5 290 100 91.06 8.94 0.427 a Reaction conditions: 1,5-dinitronaphthalene, 2g; DMF, 20mL; 20wt.% Ni/CNTs-4Catalyst, 0.1g; Temperature, 393K; H2 pressure, 0.6MPa. 1,5-Dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene over carbon nanotube supported non-noble metal catalysts under mild conditions Wei Xiong Kai-Jun Wang Xi-Wang Liu Fang Hao ⁎⁎ Han-Yan Xiao Ping-Le Liu ⁎ He-An Luo College of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, China College of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 73158298267. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were firstly thermal treated and then acid treated in HNO3 or mixture of HNO3 and H2SO4. The treated carbon nanotubes were used as support to load nickel to prepare non-noble metal hydrogenation catalysts. These catalysts were characterized and applied in 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation. The characterization results indicate that acid modified carbon nanotubes not only possess a more hydrophilic surface by introducing a variety of oxygen-containing functional groups, but also improve the nickel dispersion, hydrogen uptake quantity and metallic surface area. The Ni/CNTs catalysts show good catalytic activity in 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation under mild reaction conditions, and the Ni/CNTs-4 gives the best result of 100% conversion of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene and 92.04% selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene under 0.6MPa and 393K. The influences of reaction conditions and metal loading amount are discussed, and a possible reaction routes of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation is proposed. Such non-noble metal hydrogenation catalysts are expected to replace the present supported palladium or platinum noble catalysts in industry. Keywords 1,5-Dinitronaphthalene 1,5-Diaminonaphthalene Hydrogenation Carbon nanotubes Non-noble metal catalysts 1 Introduction Active carbon supported palladium or platinum noble metal catalysts are widely used in hydrogenation, especially in fine chemicals hydrogenation process. 1,5-diaminonaphthalene can be used in the manufacture of dyestuff, pesticide, rubber chemicals, resin and photographic materials [1]. Particularly, it is the critical material to produce 1,5-diisocyanatonaphthalene, which is an advanced polyurethane for large machinery production, the shock absorption and noise reduction of railway transportation equipments, the composite materials of wind power equipment vane, new membrane materials of solar cell module and so on [2–5]. The traditional technology of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene production suffers from many disadvantages such as the complex routes, the generation of large quantities of organic wastes and lower yield [5–8]. Hence, many researchers have tried to develop novel methods for the production of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene. In industry, the higher cost of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene lies in the use of noble metal catalysts such as Pt/C or Pd/C [9,10]. Therefore, non-noble metal catalysts have obtained more and more attention in the hydrogenation processes [11–14]. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been reported to be excellent catalyst supports based on their intrinsic properties such as high surface area, unique electronic properties and chemical inertness, thermal stability and high mechanical strength [15–20]. And carbon nanotubes supported metal catalysts exhibited high activity in hydrogenation processes [21–23], it has been assumed that the phenomenon of Hydrogen Spillover on the catalysts plays an important role. Quite a few literature are concerned with the using of modified carbon nanotubes as catalyst support [24–32]. In this paper, carbon nanotubes supported non-noble nickel catalysts were prepared and applied in 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene. It has been found that modified carbon nanotubes supported non-noble metal catalysts show good catalytic activity and selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene under mild conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The CNTs with a diameter of 10–20nm were purchased from Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co., Ltd., China. 1,5-dinitronaphthalene was purchased from Shanghai Jingchun Reagent Co., Ltd. Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) was purchased from Shanghai Aibi Chemistry Reagent Co., Ltd. And all the other reagents were analytical grade. The 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (97wt.%) standard sample was purchased from Alfa Aesar-A Johnson Matthey Company. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The raw CNTs material were denoted as CNTs-1. The raw CNTs underwent acid treatment in 65wt.% HNO3 at 303K for 12h, 50wt.% HNO3 at 373K for 4h, a mixture of HNO3 and H2SO4 (v/v =3:1) at 373K for 4h, respectively. And then the solids were washed with deionized water and dried in vacuum at 383K overnight, the corresponding materials were denoted as CNTs-2 (65wt.% HNO3), CNTs-3 (50wt.% HNO3) and CNTs-4 (HNO3 +H2SO4, v/v =3:1), respectively. The CNTs supported Ni catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. The CNTs-1, CNTs-2, CNTs-3 and CNTs-4 were mixed with an aqueous solution of 0.1M Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, stirred at 313K for 12h and dried at 373K overnight. Finally, the catalysts were calcinated at 673K for 4h in flowing nitrogen and reduced under hydrogen at 673K for 2h. The corresponding catalysts were denoted as Ni/CNTs-1, Ni/CNTs-2, Ni/CNTs-3 and Ni/CNTs-4, respectively. The metal loading content of these catalysts was 20wt.%. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The surface oxygen-containing functional groups on the CNTs supports were determined according to Boehm titration [33,34]. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the CNTs were recorded on a Nicolet 380 spectrometer. The spectra of the samples were acquired in the wavenumber range of 400–4000cm−1. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analyses of the CNTs were carried out on a CHEMBET-3000 instrument. The samples were pretreated at 373K for 18h under a flow of helium at the flow rate of 18mL/min. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of the Ni/CNTs catalysts were collected on a Japan Rigaku D/Max 2550 VB+ 18kw X-ray diffractometer under the following conditions: 40kV, 30mA, Cu Kα radiation, with a scanning rate of 10°min−1 in the range of 2θ =10–90°. The morphology of the samples were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a JSM-6610LV spectrometer and the microstructure of the catalysts were observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a TecnaiG2 20 STwin electron microscope working at less than 200kV. Hydrogen chemisorption was measured on CHEMBET 3000. The sample was previously reduced at 393K for 3h in hydrogen stream, and the adsorbed hydrogen on the nickel surface was removed under flowing nitrogen stream. The sample was subsequently cooled to ambient temperature under the nitrogen stream. The hydrogen pulses were injected until the eluted areas of consecutive pulses became constant. The amount of nickel atoms were calculated by assuming the stoichiometric adsorption of hydrogen. Nickel surface area was calculated from the nickel atomic cross-sectional area. Specific surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution of the samples were obtained by the Nitrogen adsorption–desorption on a NOVA-2200e automated gas sorption system. Specific surface areas and pore size distributions were calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods. The atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS) was tested on a AA-7000 spectrophotometer. The samples were calcinated at 873K for 12h, added into 5mL formic acid and 8mL nitrohydrochloric acid successively and dried at 358K for 2h. The treated samples were dissolved in 20mL concentrated hydrochloric acid at 353K and diluted by appropriate amount of distilled water. The nickel content of the sample was tested at λ =232nm by AAS and the loading content was obtained by the standard curve method. 2.4 Procedures for the catalytic test The liquid phase hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene was carried out in a 50mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave reactor under magnetic stirring, with 2.0g 1,5-dinitronaphthalene and 0.1g catalyst in 20mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The autoclave was sealed and flushed with hydrogen for three times, and then heated to the required temperature and pressurized with H2. After the reaction, the catalysts were removed by filtration. And the products were analyzed by a high performance liquid chromatography method. The turnover frequency is the number of product molecules formed per active site per second. In addition, for the test of reusability, the catalysts were removed from the reaction mixture by filtration and used for the next run without any other treatment. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Boehm titration results of the supports are presented in Table 1 . The results indicate that there are a small quantity of carboxylic and phenolic groups on the surface of CNTs-1. Surface modification with various oxidants leads to the increment of acidic groups [34,35]. Hence, the modified samples show significant difference in their chemical nature. CNTs-2 oxidized with 65wt.% HNO3 at 303K exhibits the presence of the lactonic groups and a small quantity of carboxylic groups, and the number of phenolic groups increases apparently. And CNTs-3 treated with 50wt.% HNO3 at 373K shows more carboxylic groups and lactonic groups than CNTs-2. Among these samples, CNTs-4 oxidized with a mixture of HNO3 and H2SO4 at 373K exhibits a significant increase of the carboxylic groups and shows the largest acidic sites on the surface. From this we can know that the pretreatment methods introduce a variety of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface, which change the physicochemical properties of the CNTs. Fig. 1 presents the FT-IR spectra of the samples. The peaks of 3440cm−1 and 1640cm−1 are attributed to OH bond stretching and bending vibrations of water. The peak around 3750cm−1 is attributed to free hydroxyl group [36], which is not obvious in CNTs-1. It may result from the residual acid through the pretreatment process. Compared with CNTs-1, other samples appear five obvious peak regions of 2800–3000cm−1, 1680–1750cm−1, 1385–1560cm−1, 1100–1170cm−1 and ∼1000cm−1. The peaks around 1680–1750cm−1 are assigned to CO stretching mode in lactones and carboxylic acids [37–39]. The peak around 1560cm−1 is related to the COO− asymmetric stretching vibration of carboxylic acids, while the peak around 1457cm−1 is due to the COO− symmetric stretching vibration, which is normally weaker than the peak of asymmetric stretching vibration [40]. And the peaks of ∼1385cm−1 and ∼1000cm−1, as well as the wide and scattered peaks around 2800–3000cm−1 are also attributed to the existence of the carboxylic acids. The peaks around 1100–1170 are assigned to the characteristic absorption peak of CO. It indicates that oxygen-containing functional groups were obtained on the outer surface of the modified CNTs. And these functional groups could improve the dispersibility of CNTs in water and enhance the specific nucleation sites for the anchoring of metal particles [41]. Fig. 2 shows the TPD results of CNTs treated with different methods. The peaks located between 450K and 750K represent the desorption of CO2 from the decomposition of carboxylic acid and the peaks located between 900K and 1150K are assigned to the desorption of CO from the decomposition of weak acids and other oxygen-containing species [42]. The number of released oxygen-containing species should correspond to the number of oxygen-containing surface groups [34]. As shown in Fig. 2, it shows the largest quantities of oxygen-containing groups in CNTs-4 with a significant volume of CO2, this agrees with the titration results. Compared with CNTs-1, the amount of decomposed groups of other samples significantly increased. The BET surface area, average pore diameter and pore volume of different carbon nanotubes are summarized in Table 2 . The untreated CNTs-1 has a specific surface area of 123.03m2 g−1 and a average pore diameter of 17.93nm. CNTs-2 and CNTs-3 oxidized with nitric acid show a slight decrement in surface area. In contrast, CNTs-4 treated with HNO3/H2SO4 represents a bigger decrement in surface area and a slight increase in average pore diameter. The results also indicate that the oxidation treatment has a little influence on the pore volume of CNTs. Fig. 3 shows the pore size distributions of the supports, CNTs-1, CNTs-2 and CNTs-3 show two regions of pore size distributions, a fine fraction (2<pore size<4nm) and a coarse fraction (pore size>4nm). The pores in the fine fraction are likely due to the amorphous carbon and the blocking of the nanotubes by the impurities, the pores in the coarse fraction are likely to be contributed by pores of carbon tubes and aggregated pores which are formed within the confined space among the isolated CNTs. A small quantity of amorphous carbon and impurities in CNTs are removed by acid treatment, which may be the reason of the decrement of the pores between 2–4nm. In addition, the slight decrement of the pore volume of CNTs treated by different acid might be related to the formation of oxygen-containing functional groups [43]. Compared with CNTs-1, other samples show a little decrease of the coarse fraction pores. The structure of Ni/CNTs catalysts were determined by XRD characterization and the results are displayed in Fig. 4 . The significant diffraction peak at 2θ =20–26° are ascribed to carbon, which indicates that these supported nickel catalysts have uniform crystal structure of carbon. The significant diffraction peaks at 2θ =44°, 52°, and 77° are ascribed to nickel. And Ni/CNTs-2, Ni/CNTs-3 and Ni/CNTs-4 show better purity of carbon than Ni/CNTs-1. It indicates that acid treatment could remove some amorphous carbon and impurity species. Ni/CNTs-4 has weaker diffraction peaks of nickel than the other samples, which indicates the existence of well dispersed nickel phases. The hydrogen chemisorption data are shown in Table 3 . It can be seen from Table that Ni/CNTs-1 exhibits the lowest dispersion, hydrogen uptake quantity and metallic surface area, Ni/CNTs-4 shows the best dispersion, larger hydrogen uptake quantity and metallic surface areas, which might favor the 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation process. From the above characterizations we can know that the purity and surface nature of the CNTs were greatly improved after acid modification, it becomes more hydrophilic and suitable for metal ion loading and dispersion. The SEM and TEM images of the catalysts are shown in Figs. 5 and 6 . Ni/CNTs-1 displays compact structure and has caking phenomenon. Nickel particles in Ni/CNTs-1 agglomerate seriously. However, Ni/CNTs-3 and Ni/CNTs-4 show looser structure and well dispersed nickel phases in Fig. 5. Compared with Ni/CNTs-1, Ni/CNTs-4 shows looser structure and better dispersion of nickel particles in Fig. 6. Moreover, the nickel particle size distributions show that the nickel particle size in Ni/CNTs-4 mainly fall into the scope of 6nm–12nm and the nickel particles uniformly distribute along the outer surface of the nanotubes. However, as for Ni/CNTs-1, the nickel particles distribute unequally and parts of the small nickel particles enter into the nanotubes and a majority of nickel particles agglomerate seriously out of the tubes, which may result in unsatisfactory hydrogenation performance. 3.2 Catalytic performance The results of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation over the above prepared catalysts are summarized in Table 4 . It can be seen from Table that the CNTs-4 treated with HNO3 and H2SO4 without nickel metal does not show catalytic activity in the hydrogenation reaction. The catalytic activity and the 1,5-diaminonaphthalene selectivity increase significantly over the acid modified CNTs supported nickel catalysts. Ni/CNTs-4 gives 100% conversion of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene and 91.18% selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene in the shortest time. It takes 330min for the 100% conversion of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene over Ni/CNTs-1 and the selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene is only 86.52%. Nickel dispersion, hydrogen uptake quantity and metallic surface area can be improved on acid modified CNTs. CNTs-4 treated with HNO3 and H2SO4 presents the best nickel dispersion, the largest hydrogen uptake quantity and metallic surface area, hence CNTs-4 supported nickel catalyst gives the best catalytic performance. 3.3 The possible reaction routes On the basis of the results of LC–MS and GC–MS, it can be found that besides the main product 1,5-diaminonaphthalene, other products such as the intermediate of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine, the hydrazonaphthylamine are also detected. The reaction time was controlled to obtain the intermediate product, so as to confirm the possible reaction routes. It could be found that only one stable intermediate formed during the reaction. The intermediate product was purified to 99% in N,N-dimethylformamide. The FT-IR spectra of the intermediate product are shown in Fig. 7 . The sample appears four peak regions of 3409cm−1, 1571–1631cm−1, 1318–1514cm−1, and 778cm−1. The peaks of ∼3400cm−1 and 1560–1640cm−1 are usually to determine the existence of the ArNH2 [44]. And the extremely strong peaks around 1535cm−1 and 1345cm−1 are assigned to asymmetric stretching vibration and symmetric stretching vibration of ArNO2 [44]. The peaks around 778cm−1 are related to the three adjacent hydrogen in the naphthalene ring. With the results of LC–MS and GC–MS, it can be said that the stable intermediate is 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine. The intermediate of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine is the incomplete hydrogenation product, which could transform to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene when the reaction proceeds. The hydrazonaphthylamine might be obtained from hydrogenation of azoxycompounds (ArNN(O)Ar), which is formed by the reaction of the nitrosocompounds (ArNO) and hydroxylamine compounds (ArNHOH) during the reaction route [45,46]. A possible routes of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation was proposed in Scheme 1 . 3.4 Influence of the Ni loading amount The influences of Ni loading amount of Ni/CNTs-4 were studied under 393K and 1.0MPa H2 pressure. It can be seen from Table 5 that 1,5-dinitronaphthalene conversion increases from 58.76% to 100% with the increment of the Ni loading amount. And the selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene increases significantly with the conversion of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine. The best nickel loading amount for Ni/CNTs-4 is 20wt.%. 3.5 Influence of the reaction conditions The effects of reaction temperature were investigated under reaction time of 120min and 1.0MPa H2 pressure. It can be seen from Table 6 that the reaction temperature plays an important role in 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation. From 363K to 383K, a large amount of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine cannot be transformed to the desired products, which leads to lower selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene. It shows that 393K is the most suitable reaction temperature. The selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene decreases when the reaction temperature increases to 403K, the reason maybe the side reaction to hydrazonaphthylamine, which is determined by LC–MS analysis. The effects of H2 pressure were studied under 393K and reaction time of 120min. It can be seen from Table 7 that the conversion of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene increases from 78.86% to 100% when H2 pressure increases from 0.2MPa to 0.4MPa. However, over half the intermediate 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine cannot be transformed to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene under 0.4MPa at 120min, hence the selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene is only 36.86%. It shows that the 1,5-dinitronaphthalene conversion is up to 100% and the selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene reaches the maximum value when H2 pressure is 0.6MPa. The effects of reaction time were studied under 393K and 0.6MPa H2 pressure. It can be seen from Table 8 that the intermediate 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine cannot be transformed to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene when the reaction time is less than 120min. The selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene increases to 92.04% when all the intermediate 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine converted to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene and the reaction reaches to the endpoint in 120min. Moreover, the selectivity does not increase obviously when the reaction time prolongs further to 150min. 3.6 The reusability of catalyst The results of catalyst recycling are shown in Table 9 . After each reaction, Ni/CNTs-4 catalysts were separated by filtration and then used for the next turn without any other treatment. It can be seen that the yield of 1,5-diaminonaphthalene exceeded 91% after the fifth use except for an extension of reaction time. The reason for the extension of reaction time may be the leaching of the Ni on the surface. This is testified by the AAS analysis of the nickel loading amount of the recycle catalyst. The nickel loading amount decreases from 20% to 18% after the fifth use. Another reason for the slight decrement of the catalytic activity may be that a portion of the active sites were covered with organic materials since the recycled catalysts do not undergo any other treatment. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, nickel was supported on the modified carbon nanotubes to prepare non-noble metal catalysts by impregnation method. The characterization results indicate that carbon nanotubes undergo acid treatment were introduced a variety of oxygen-containing functional groups, which is help to improve the metal dispersion, hydrogen uptake quantity and metallic surface area. It shows that 20wt.% Ni/CNTs-4 gives the best catalytic performance of 100% conversion of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene and 92.04% selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene under mild reaction conditions of 393K and 0.6MPa H2 pressure. The possible reaction routes is proposed based on LC–MC, GC–MC and FT-IR results. Such non-noble metal hydrogenation catalysts are expected to replace the present supported palladium and platinum noble metal catalysts in industry. coredata.dc:description: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were firstly thermal treated and then acid treated in HNO3 or mixture of HNO3 and H2SO4. The treated carbon nanotubes were used as support to load nickel to prepare non-noble metal hydrogenation catalysts. These catalysts were characterized and applied in 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation. The characterization results indicate that acid modified carbon nanotubes not only possess a more hydrophilic surface by introducing a variety of oxygen-containing functional groups, but also improve the nickel dispersion, hydrogen uptake quantity and metallic surface area. The Ni/CNTs catalysts show good catalytic activity in 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation under mild reaction conditions, and the Ni/CNTs-4 gives the best result of 100% conversion of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene and 92.04% selectivity to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene under 0.6MPa and 393K. The influences of reaction conditions and metal loading amount are discussed, and a possible reaction routes of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation is proposed. Such non-noble metal hydrogenation catalysts are expected to replace the present supported palladium or platinum noble catalysts in industry.
coredata.dc:title: 1,5-Dinitronaphthalene hydrogenation to 1,5-diaminonaphthalene over carbon nanotube supported non-noble metal catalysts under mild conditions
